utils.types.control_outputsÂ¶

Source: src\utils\types\control_outputs.py

Module OverviewÂ¶

Structured return types for controllers.

This module defines a collection of NamedTuple classes that formalise the output contract of the various controller classes in this project. Each controller returns an instance of a corresponding named tuple rather than a bare tuple. Returning a named tuple preserves backward compatibility with existing code that expects a tuple (because a named tuple inherits from tuple) while also exposing descriptive attribute names to clarify the meaning of each element. Explicit interfaces act as contracts between caller and callee: the client must satisfy preconditions and may rely on the supplier to guarantee postconditions. As noted in interfaceâ€‘based programming literature, the tighter the contract (for example through explicit return types), the less freedom the implementation has to deviate from expectationsã€738473614585036â€ L239-L256ã€‘. By codifying controller outputs in named tuples, we communicate the structure of the returned data unambiguously and reduce the risk of misinterpretation by downstream components.

ReferencesÂ¶

  • F.Â Steimann and P.Â Mayer, â€œPatterns of interfaceâ€‘based programming,â€ Journal of Object Technology, vol.Â 4, no.Â 7, pp.Â 75â€“94, 2005. The authors view interfaces as contracts between a client and a supplier, emphasising that clear preconditions and postconditions constrain the behaviour of implementationsã€738473614585036â€ L239-L256ã€‘. Encoding controller outputs as named tuples tightens the return contract and prevents ambiguous slicing or misuse.

Complete Source CodeÂ¶

  1#======================================================================================\\\
  2#========================= src/utils/types/control_outputs.py =========================\\\
  3#======================================================================================\\\
  4
  5"""
  6Structured return types for controllers.
  7
  8This module defines a collection of `NamedTuple` classes that formalise the
  9output contract of the various controller classes in this project.  Each
 10controller returns an instance of a corresponding named tuple rather than
 11a bare tuple.  Returning a named tuple preserves backward compatibility
 12with existing code that expects a tuple (because a named tuple inherits
 13from ``tuple``) while also exposing descriptive attribute names to clarify
 14the meaning of each element.  Explicit interfaces act as contracts
 15between caller and callee: the client must satisfy preconditions and
 16may rely on the supplier to guarantee postconditions.  As noted in
 17interfaceâ€‘based programming literature, the tighter the contract (for
 18example through explicit return types), the less freedom the
 19implementation has to deviate from expectationsã€738473614585036â€ L239-L256ã€‘.  By
 20codifying controller outputs in named tuples, we communicate the
 21structure of the returned data unambiguously and reduce the risk of
 22misinterpretation by downstream components.
 23
 24References
 25----------
 26- F.Â Steimann and P.Â Mayer, â€œPatterns of interfaceâ€‘based programming,â€ *Journal
 27  of Object Technology*, vol.Â 4, no.Â 7, pp.Â 75â€“94, 2005.  The authors view
 28  interfaces as contracts between a client and a supplier, emphasising that
 29  clear preconditions and postconditions constrain the behaviour of
 30  implementationsã€738473614585036â€ L239-L256ã€‘.  Encoding controller outputs as named
 31  tuples tightens the return contract and prevents ambiguous slicing or
 32  misuse.
 33"""
 34
 35from __future__ import annotations
 36
 37from typing import NamedTuple, Tuple, Dict, Any
 38
 39
 40class ClassicalSMCOutput(NamedTuple):
 41    """Return type for :class:`classical_smc.ClassicalSMC.compute_control`.
 42
 43    Parameters
 44    ----------
 45    u : float
 46        The saturated control input applied to the actuator (N).
 47    state : Tuple[(), ...]
 48        Tuple representing internal controller state.  Classical SMC has
 49        no internal state, so this is always an empty tuple.
 50    history : Dict[str, Any]
 51        A history dictionary used to record intermediate variables for
 52        debugging or plotting.  May be empty.
 53    """
 54
 55    u: float
 56    state: Tuple[Any, ...]
 57    history: Dict[str, Any]
 58
 59
 60class AdaptiveSMCOutput(NamedTuple):
 61    """Return type for :class:`adaptive_smc.AdaptiveSMC.compute_control`.
 62
 63    Parameters
 64    ----------
 65    u : float
 66        The saturated control input (N).
 67    state : Tuple[float, ...]
 68        A tuple containing the updated integrator or adaptation states
 69        returned by the controller.  The length of this tuple depends on
 70        the controller implementation (e.g., leak integrator value).
 71    history : Dict[str, Any]
 72        Dictionary capturing intermediate variables and trajectories.
 73    sigma : float
 74        Current sliding surface value.  Exposing sigma allows the caller
 75        to monitor the switching surface and verify sliding mode
 76        convergence.  Providing it here rather than reâ€‘computing avoids
 77        redundant calculations.
 78    """
 79
 80    u: float
 81    state: Tuple[float, ...]
 82    history: Dict[str, Any]
 83    sigma: float
 84
 85
 86class STAOutput(NamedTuple):
 87    """Return type for superâ€‘twisting controllers.
 88
 89    Parameters
 90    ----------
 91    u : float
 92        The bounded control input (N).
 93    state : Tuple[float, float]
 94        A tuple containing the auxiliary integrator states (e.g., ``z`` and
 95        ``sigma``).  These states evolve according to the superâ€‘twisting
 96        algorithm and are needed to resume control in the next time step.
 97    history : Dict[str, Any]
 98        History information for diagnostics and plotting.
 99    sigma : float
100        Current sliding surface value. Exposing sigma allows batch simulation
101        and Lyapunov validation tests to monitor convergence without re-computing.
102    """
103
104    u: float
105    state: Tuple[float, ...]
106    history: Dict[str, Any]
107    sigma: float
108
109
110class HybridSTAOutput(NamedTuple):
111    """Return type for :class:`hybrid_adaptive_sta_smc.HybridAdaptiveSTASMC.compute_control`.
112
113    Parameters
114    ----------
115    u : float
116        The saturated control input.
117    state : Tuple[float, float, float]
118        Tuple containing the adaptive gains and integral state, e.g.,
119        ``(k1, k2, u_int)``.
120    history : Dict[str, Any]
121        Dictionary capturing trajectories of gains, the integral term
122        and the sliding surface.
123    sigma : float
124        Current sliding surface value.
125    """
126
127    u: float
128    state: Tuple[float, ...]
129    history: Dict[str, Any]
130    sigma: float

Usage ExamplesÂ¶

Example 1: Basic UsageÂ¶

# Basic usage example
from src.utils import Component

component = Component()
result = component.process(data)

Example 2: Advanced ConfigurationÂ¶

# Advanced configuration
component = Component(
    option1=value1,
    option2=value2
)

Example 3: Integration with FrameworkÂ¶

# Integration example
from src.simulation import SimulationRunner

runner = SimulationRunner()
runner.use_component(component)

Example 4: Performance OptimizationÂ¶

# Performance-optimized usage
component = Component(enable_caching=True)

Example 5: Error HandlingÂ¶

# Error handling
try:
    result = component.process(data)
except ComponentError as e:
    print(f"Error: {e}")
